review_text:
Scope and dataset: We reviewed 2023–2025 work on multiclass ECG arrhythmia classification using MIT-BIH (AAMI 5-class: N, S/SVEB, V/VEB, F, Q), focusing on sequence inputs comparable to 2-lead, ~1000-sample windows and PyTorch feasibility. A key methodological point is to evaluate with the inter-patient (DS1→DS2) split recommended by De Chazal et al., since intra-patient setups consistently inflate results. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/html/2404.15367v1?utm_source=openai))
Recent SOTA-style models and findings:
- Tiny Transformer (ViT-style for 1D): 6k parameters; 8-bit quantized inference 4.28 ms and 0.09 mJ on GAP9 MCU; reports 98.97% accuracy on MIT-BIH 5-class but explicitly uses an intra-patient protocol. Architecture takes a ~0.5 s beat window plus pre/post RR intervals. Excellent for embedded efficiency but not inter-patient. ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2402.10748))
- CNN + entropy-rate and RR-interval features: beat-level classifier evaluated under both protocols; reports 97.91% average accuracy for 5-class inter-patient and 98.73% (3-class) on MIT-BIH; also generalizes to INCART. Shows the value of fusing morphology with timing (RR). ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39021157/?utm_source=openai))
- Adversarial Beat-Score-Map (BSM) framework for inter-patient robustness: introduces pretraining with adversarial learning on beat-score maps and improves inter-patient F1 by 14.27% on MIT-BIH; also shows gains in AFib detection where inter-patient variability is large. ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/14/16/7227?utm_source=openai))
- Inter-patient MLP + Weight Capsule + Seq2Seq: reports 99.88% overall accuracy on MIT-BIH (AAMI 5-class) with DS1→DS2; unusually high compared to typical inter-patient results—useful as a reference but warrants caution and replication. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37841320/))
- Multi-lead lightweight CNN with channel attention: targets 2-lead and 12-lead settings; reports ~99.18% accuracy (dataset-specific); protocol details (inter- vs intra-patient) vary—illustrates effectiveness of lead-attention for multi-lead inputs. ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/1424-8220/25/17/5542?utm_source=openai))
- InceptionTime variants with attention/SE: Although many results are on PTB-XL or mixed datasets, InceptionTime-based backbones with Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) regularly outperform plain CNNs for ECG time series, and PyTorch implementations are mature and efficient. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2312.09445?utm_source=openai))
Surveys/meta-analyses emphasize that: (i) CNN-based models dominate, (ii) inter-patient accuracy is much lower than intra-patient, and (iii) many papers lack standardized evaluation and embedded-feasibility reporting—necessitating careful split adherence and reporting. ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/8/4964?utm_source=openai))
Practical implications for your setting (torch_tensor, shape [1000, 2], 5 classes): Models that (a) process multivariate 1D sequences directly, (b) integrate RR-interval context, and (c) use class-imbalance-aware training are most aligned. InceptionTime-style multiscale 1D convolutions with SE attention are well-suited to 2-channel, 1000-sample inputs and are compute-efficient; adding a small fusion branch for RR intervals consistently helps SVEB/VEB detection. Tiny-Transformer designs are attractive for edge deployment but should be revalidated under DS1→DS2 for fair comparison. ([williamsdoug.github.io](https://williamsdoug.github.io/tsai/models.InceptionTime.html?utm_source=openai))
key_findings: Evaluation protocol matters: inter-patient (DS1→DS2) performance is typically far lower than intra-patient; standardized splits and reporting are essential for fair comparison. ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/8/4964?utm_source=openai))

Lightweight Transformer for ECG (≈6k params) achieves 98.97% accuracy on MIT-BIH 5-class with 8-bit inference and 0.09 mJ per prediction, but results are intra-patient; it also fuses RR intervals with beat windows. ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2402.10748))

Combining morphology with timing features (RR intervals or beat-score maps) improves inter-patient generalization; e.g., CNN+RR achieves 97.91% inter-patient accuracy (5-class), and adversarial BSM pretraining boosts inter-patient F1 by 14.27%. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39021157/?utm_source=openai))
recommended_approaches: Multivariate InceptionTime with Squeeze-and-Excitation (InceptionTime-SE) plus RR-interval fusion: Use a 1D InceptionTime backbone (PyTorch/tsai implementations) on [B, C=2, L=1000] inputs with SE blocks for channel-wise attention; add a small MLP branch for pre-/post-/local/global RR intervals and fuse via concatenation before the classifier. Train with DS1→DS2 inter-patient split (AAMI 5-class), class-balanced focal loss, and mixup/augmentation. This architecture matches your 2-channel sequence shape, has strong empirical backing for ECG time series, balances accuracy and compute (sub-1–2M params typical), and is readily implemented in PyTorch. ([williamsdoug.github.io](https://williamsdoug.github.io/tsai/models.InceptionTime.html?utm_source=openai))
